abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Eastern Lowlands Natural
            Resource Management and Agricultural Production Project for
            Bolivia are as follows: outcome of the project was
            satisfactory, sustainability of the project was good, and
            the performance of the Bank and the Borrower was rated as
            satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned from the project
            are: a) it is important for the Bank to bring issues of the
            environment, ethnicity or gender to the development dialogue
            in countries where these issues are still not on the agenda.
            In the case of the Eastern Lowlands Project, International
            Development Association (IDA's) role in introducing
            environmental and indigenous concerns into the development
            dialogue in Santa Cruz was crucial; b) it is important for
            the Bank to explore other channels in civil society to solve
            developmental or social problems. This was important in the
            indigenous component where IDA's persistence and
            patience in resolving the issues paid off. This was an
            extremely conflictive issue that required several years to
            solve but which IDA considered to be very important. Working
            closely with civil society i.e. beneficiaries,
            non-government organization (NGOs), churches etc., finally
            led to a solution of the crisis. IDA insisting on a
            declared" bottom line" result helped in this
            sense; and c) mid-term reviews can be very useful when the
            problems are clearly identified by both the Borrower and the
            Bank. In this case, the mid-term review was very beneficial,
            as the problems were clearly identified and the scope of the
            restructuring was judicious. This restructuring led to a
            refocusing on the "public good" issues that needed
            to be financed to accompany the privately financed
            development that was going on in the project area, i.e.
            improvement of roads into small farmer areas, increased
            research and extension on sustainable practices, and renewal
            of commitment to indigenous issues.
